title: HTML attribute: Draggable
post: {{Sidebar("web/html/reference/global_attributes")}} The **`draggable`** [global attribute](/blog/Web/HTML/Reference/Global_attributes) is an [enumerated](/blog/Glossary/Enumerated) attribute that indicates whether the element can be dragged, either with native browser behavior or the [HTML Drag and Drop API](/blog/Web/API/HTML_Drag_and_Drop_API). The `draggable` attribute may be applied to elements that strictly fall under the [HTML namespace](/blog/Glossary/Namespace), which means that it cannot be applied to [SVGs](/blog/Web/SVG). For more information about what namespace declarations look like, and what they do, see [Namespace crash course](/blog/Web/SVG/Guides/Namespaces_crash_course). `draggable` can have the following values: - `true`: the element can be dragged. - `false`: the element cannot be dragged. > [!WARNING] > This attribute is _[enumerated](/blog/Glossary/Enumerated)_ and not _Boolean_. A value of `true` or `false` is mandatory, and shorthand like `` is forbidden. The correct usage is ``. If this attribute is not set, its default value is `auto`, which means drag behavior is the default browser behavior: only text selections, images, and links can be dragged. For other elements, the event {{domxref('HTMLElement.dragstart_event', 'ondragstart')}} must be set for drag and drop to work, as shown in this [comprehensive example](/blog/Web/API/HTML_Drag_and_Drop_API/Drag_operations). ## Specifications {{Specifications}} ## Browser compatibility {{Compat}} ## See also - All [global attributes](/blog/Web/HTML/Reference/Global_attributes).
